text: Back in the days when I was a rookie in the police force, the Chief was a veteran. He had caught a notorious criminal – or had been awarded for bravery. But he had – a young daughter.
keypoint: Reflecting on the Chief and his daughter

text: And in those days I was a fitness enthusiast. And it seemed she was trying to impress me. I never observed it.
keypoint: Narrator's fitness and the daughter's interest

text: Truth is I wasn't very fond of her because she was – She was a charming girl until she opened her mouth. She was a chatterbox. Goodness, she could talk.
keypoint: Narrator's annoyance with the daughter's chatter

text: Then she left a message one day saying she was going to run away because he was always scolding her about me. He arrived at my apartment. Big intimidating look on his face. I managed to calm him down.
keypoint: Chief confronts narrator about his daughter

text: and proposed “Well we'll search for her and if we can't locate her well you can – do whatever you think is right.” I was strategizing. So he accepted my offer.
keypoint: Narrator's strategy to find the Chief's daughter

text: And we went to where they found her scarf – near a park. and we traced down a little more and we couldn't locate her. And returned
– it was a police station – she was sitting on a chair with a book in her hands. She hadn't run away. But – nevertheless – that resolved the issue for that day.
keypoint: Finding the Chief's daughter at the station

text: But that evening the deputy, Frank Mitchell, said “You better transfer and leave because that old man never forgets anything once he gets it into his mind.” And I did. I transferred. and left.
keypoint: Deputy's advice leads to narrator's transfer

text: That was the end of my rookie year.
keypoint: End of the narrator's rookie year
